At 03:11 AM 4/21/03 +0000, you wrote:
>...Thanks for all the replies. Some of them have been helpful (ie. the
>one that pointed me to jboss, cactus), althought most of 'em aren't.
>I've decided to go to a bookstore and pickup a book on EJB. I
>figured if i get familiar with EJB, it might be easier to understand
>the testing itself.

disclamer, i am not an ejb expert, but:

the ejb's llive in a ejb container (like jboss or webshere), servlets live 
in a servlet container (like tomcat).

ejb's are complicated and the're are a few flavours: session, entity, 
message etc. (note: a java bean is *not* part of the ejb stuff - neither 
are these mbeans - i think)

this stuff is mult--tiered (i.e. at least client server, hence cactus).

a lot of them are called from inside servlets (or jsp's - which are servlets).

so if you end up with something that tests the ejb, you will probably need 
all of the other stuff unless you somehow do a cactus-like number and fake 
out a container for the ejb's to live in - which would be really cool, but 
given the spec, probably *very* hard.

hmmm, i had not looked at cactus lately, but look here: 
http://jakarta.apache.org/cactus/index.html for where your stuff might fit 
in. try to grok this: http://jakarta.apache.org/cactus/how_it_works.html

but i would keep an eye out fot that "ejb sample" that is coming rsn. maybe 
join the cactus list and its' developers list.

thanks
